evals.prompt: Create a simple Playdate game in C with a moving player sprite. The player should move left and right with the D-pad, and the crank controls their speed. Show me the main.c entry point and the player update logic.
evals.expected_output: Playdate C code with proper eventHandler entry point, PlaydateAPI global, player struct using snake_case, crank input handling, and Playdate-specific APIs.
expectations: The code includes the eventHandler function as the entry point
A global PlaydateAPI pointer (g_pd) is declared
The code uses Playdate APIs via g_pd (e.g., g_pd->system->getButtonState, g_pd->system->getCrankChange)
The player is represented as a struct with snake_case fields
Memory allocation uses g_pd->system->realloc instead of malloc
The game uses g_pd->system->setUpdateCallback for the game loop

evals.prompt: I'm working on a Playdate shoot-em-up. How do I implement a bullet pool system in C to avoid runtime memory allocation? Show me the pool structure and how to spawn/return bullets.
evals.expected_output: A C implementation of an object pool for bullets, using static arrays or the Playdate allocator, with proper snake_case naming and Playdate-specific patterns.
expectations: The pool avoids runtime malloc/free in the game loop
The bullet pool uses a struct with snake_case field names
The implementation uses a fixed-size array or pre-allocated memory
The code includes functions for getting a bullet from the pool and returning it
